message: I was told yrs ago partitioning disks can have slight performance benefit. This is not the case w/ Virtual / Hyper-V disks, right? Nor SSDs?

data.message: What kind of performance you're trying to measure ? Reading/Writing data? By far SSDs are the fastest of course, they have no mechanical structure, as a pure analog control circuits, but SSDs are pure digital, and their SATA interface speed SATA, > 1.5 Gbit/s.
Of course I'm not asking whether SSDs are faster :D :D

It used to be said that sort of physical load distribution happens when you run things on multiple partitions, that is less than multiple physical disks, and is more than a single partition. I was wondering whether the same wisdom applies to SSDs, and whether it applies to virtual disks as well (Hyper-V in particular, if it makes a difference).
I don't know why would partitioning disks can increase the performance ? maybe someone elaborate the technical idea behind that.
Partitioning has little real world significance in terms of performance... if you want that you should look for RAID configs or SSDs or the 10krpm HDDS

To be more specific, I have a Hyper-V VM (VPS), with SSD disk, I was wondering whether I'd gain any performance by partitioning it, or not worth it (with backup / disaster recovery aside for this question).
Short answer, no! but you can try it out and run some benchmarks.. the difference will mainly be synthetic.
I don't think so, SSDs their own structure (memory mapped), lets you to read the data very fast regardless of the partitions. basically consider your SSD is just a normal Flash Memory.
I'm kind of leaning towards "No" as well. For being a virtual disk more than for being SSD, but needed validation from someone else, not to just depend on guessing.
No. Partitioning will not increase performance.
